item.title: Productive College Life II: Organization
item.description: Organizing your college life can be incredibly daunting. When I began as a freshman I can distinctly remember being overwhelmed by the sheer amount of new information being thrown at me daily. I now finally feel like I have a few methods for staying on top of my game and keeping my stress levels lower. So let’s explore how systematically keeping track of your schedule, emails, and files can keep your workflow as streamlined and efficient.

item.title: Productive College Life I: Budgeting
item.description: I’ve been toying with the idea of writing a post like this for a few months now. There are endless blogs and vlogs offering tips and tricks to students on how to successfully navigate the minefield of being an independent college student for their first time. However, I feel like sharing the various technology and productivity strategies that have added structure to many aspects of my life, which in turn has allowed me to stress less about life and put more focus on being an organized and motivated student.

item.title: Journal Recreation: Approximate Bayesian computation for disease outbreaks
item.description: This post is a summary of the final project that I completed for my Statistical Computing course in my first semester of grad school. The goal of this project was to recreate two figures from a paper authored by Tony and Stumpf, “Simulation-based model selection for dynamical systems in systems and population biology”. This paper uses the approximate bayesian computation (or ABC) algorithm to model a few fairly complex statistical models.

item.title: Now
item.description: I had to move back home due to COVID-19. Currently reading How Charts Lie, by Alberto Cairo, and The Signal and the Noise, by Nate Silver. Currently working on migrating my old website to Hugo.

item.title: Viewing xkcd comics in RStudio
item.description: I love the webcomic xkcd, and I look forward to seeing the new comic whenever. The problem is, sometimes I’m forgetful and I forget to check the website for the latest comic (or sometimes comics if I’m really behind). But luckily for me, I do use RStudio everyday. This made me realize that “hey, maybe I should make something so I can able to view xkcd in RStudio.” So I did.

item.title: Using 1.6 Million Tweets with a Markov Chain Text Generator
item.description: During my daily dose of reddit browsing, I came across this post and was subsequently pretty confused. How can an office be THAT high? Amidst my bewilderment, I noticed that it came from the subreddit SubredditSimulator, and its hilarity immediately grabbed my attention. If you are unfamiliar with how Reddit operates, it is basically a giant forum split into thousands of subcommunities called “subreddits.” Users are allowed to subscribe to whatever subreddits they want to so they can regularly view its content, create posts in any subreddit, and comment on any post they like.

item.title: Remaking Visualizations from 538
item.description: Fivethirtyeight is one of my favorite news websites for interesting political articles and insightful sports predictions. Fivethirtyeight is spearheaded by Editor in Chief Nate Silver, the popular statistician who wrote the excellent book, The Signal and the Noise. But what I truly love about Fivethirtyeight is their unbiased and objective approach to their methodology, and how they present their data through their visualizations. They use a fairly clean and minimal style, following the idea of a low data-ink ratio, which is something I try to replicate in my own visualizations.

item.title: Examining the 2016 Presidential Election
item.description: A Leaflet map of the 2016 U.S. Election The United States 2016 presidential election seemed like it would be an easy victory for the DNC’s Hillary Clinton over the GOP’s Donald Trump. However, Trump came out the victor, depsite losing the popular vote by three million votes. This election has inspired me to dig deeper into the voting data. Through this investigation, I also wanted to become more familiar with choropleth maps in R, and make them interactive using the leaflet package.

item.title: About Me
item.description: Hi! My name is Joe Stoica. I’m a graduate student from Indiana University pursuing a master’s degree in statistical science. This coming summer, I’ll be interning at Cook Medical, where I’ll be a statistics intern in their Quality Engineering department. This previous summer I was the media analytics intern at MullenLowe Mediahub, where I assisted in data analysis and reporting for advertising campaigns. I’ve previously worked at Upland Brewing Co., where I compiled and analyzed supply chain data, and with the Cognitive Development Lab at IU, where I completed a semester long analysis project regarding the pathways for how children learn the mathematical concept of place value.
